But my father also told me that he loved her, and that he would do anything for her, and I accepted it. I loved my mother.   Back then, my mother never cared much for me, but in her place, there was my father. My father cared for me, and he did all that a mother should've done for her child. My mother had never been caring, so I did not have a caring mother -- but I did not know my loss. When we went to the park, the other children gathered around their mothers, asking for snacks and food. I knew that my mother should have been the one to humour me, but instead, I had my father. And in her place, he did a fine job.   In my youth, my father was my everything -- he was my rock, my role model, and my sole guide. As I grew, my mother seemed to become happier and more cheerful. Her dissatisfaction with me, with my father, and with our family seemed to ebb. In its place, there grew a sort of odd fondness.   When I was 14, my father took me to the side, and with him, I promised that I would love my mother forever.    She's trying to change for us,  he said.  She loves us.    And it seemed to be that way, and we were all happy. Indeed, my mother slowly changed, and she changed for all the better -- instead of distance, we formed a close relationship. She apologized for all the years during which she had n't paid attention to me, and I, wishing for our family to become like all the others, accepted her apology. When I did, she smiled, and hugged me tight. I could smell her perfume -- soft, floral, and with a faint hint of citrus. I had never like the scent of flowers ( nor that of perfume ) very much, but hers calmed me, and I relaxed into her embrace. I told her this, and she began to hug me frequently, soothing me with soft words and gently cuddling me.   I still admired my father greatly, but now, I had another guide -- my mother. She was finally there for me, and for our family. I was content and cheerful like never before. And my father, too, was happy. We grew closer, not only as family, but also as a father and his child.   When I was 40, my father had to go to the hospital. When the hospital called me, I rushed to arrive as quickly as I could, and I found my mother sobbing in the waiting room. We were told that he would probably make it.   He passed six hours later, and my mother and I wept. I cried as we were escorted from the room. Then, I knew the loss of a parent, and I felt haunted -- what if I had spent more time with him? Now, sitting around a table and surrounded by people I love, I grin mischievously at my wife.    You look gorgeous, hun,  I say.   She's smiling at me, and there's a blush on her face. I go up to her, and I hug her from behind. Then, I hug my mother, who's seated beside her.    I'm so glad you're here with me, today,  I say.  I can love both of you, now and forever.
